Crossing-over between homologous chromosomes during meiosis is necessary for the proper segregation of the chromosomes. In the fly species Drosophila melanogaster, two conserved genes, <math alttext="m e i 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">mei-9</mtext></math> and <math alttext="p c h 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">pch2</mtext></math>, are thought to play a role in crossing-over. The protein encoded by <math alttext="m e i 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">mei-9</mtext></math> is part of a large protein complex required for the pairing of homologous chromosomes, while the protein encoded by <math alttext="p c h 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">pch2</mtext></math> is associated with a delay in prophase <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> that is believed to serve as a cell cycle checkpoint. To investigate the role of <math alttext="m e i 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">mei-9</mtext></math> and <math alttext="p c h 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">pch2</mtext></math> in crossing-over, researchers determined the frequency of recombination for each of four regions of chromosome <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> in wild-type flies (<math alttext="W T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>WT</mtext></math>), flies expressing a mutant form of <math alttext="m e i 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">mei-9</mtext></math> (<math alttext="m e i 9 m u t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mei-9-mut</mtext></math> flies), and flies expressing mutant forms of both <math alttext="m e i 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">mei-9</mtext></math> and <math alttext="p c h 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">pch2</mtext></math> (<math alttext="m e i 9 m u t slash p c h 2 m u t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mei-9-mut/pch2-mut</mtext></math> flies). The frequency of recombination of each region in both types of mutant flies is shown in Figure 1 as a percentage of the frequency of recombination observed in <math alttext="W T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>WT</mtext></math> flies. Figure 1. Frequency of recombination of four regions of chromosome <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> in <math alttext="m e i 9 m u t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mei-9-mut</mtext></math> flies and <math alttext="m e i 9 m u t slash p c h 2 m u t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mei-9-mut/pch2-mut</mtext></math> flies as a percentage of the frequency of recombination in the same region in wild-type flies (a) Based on the data in Figure 1, identify the region of chromosome <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> with the greatest frequency of recombination in <math alttext="m e i 9 m u t slash p c h 2 m u t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mei-9-mut/pch2-mut</mtext></math> flies.
